But Jonesy never having known anything of fathers whose chief pleasure is in spending money to make little sons happy, was not comforted by that promise as much as Keith thought he ought to be.
column3: Never mind, Jonesy, he said, "papa will be home in the spring and he'll send you back to Barney." But Jonesy never having known anything of fathers whose chief pleasure is in spending money to make little sons happy, was not comforted by that promise as much as Keith thought he ought to be.

column2: But I won't be here then, he sobbed.
column3: But I won't be here then, he sobbed.

column2: They're goin' to put me in a 'sylum, and I can't get out for so long that maybe Barney will be dead before we ever find each other again.
column3: They're goin' to put me in a 'sylum, and I can't get out for so long that maybe Barney will be dead before we ever find each other again.

column2: He was crying violently now.
column3: He was crying violently now.

column2: Who is going to put you in an asylum? asked Malcolm, lifting an end of the pillow under which Jonesy's head had burrowed, to hide the grief that his eight-year-old manhood made him too proud to show.
column3: Who is going to put you in an asylum? asked Malcolm, lifting an end of the pillow under which Jonesy's head had burrowed, to hide the grief that his eight year old manhood made him too proud to show.

column2: An old lady with white hair what comes here every day.	An old lady with white hair what comes here every day.
column3: true

column2: The professor said he would keep me if he wasn't so old and hard up, and she said as how a 'sylum was the proper place for a child of the slums, and he said yes if they wasn't nobody to care for 'em.
column3: The professor said he would keep me if he wasn't so old and hard up, and she said as how a 'sylum was the proper place for a child of the slums, and he said yes if they wasn't nobody to care for 'em.

column2: But I've got somebody!" he cried.
column3: But I've got somebody!" he cried.

column2: I've got Barney!	I've got Barney!
column3: true

column2: Oh, _don't_ let them shut me up somewhere so I can't never get back to Barney!"
column3: Oh, underscore don't underscore let them shut me up somewhere so I can't never get back to Barney!"

column2: They don't shut you up when they send you to an asylum, said Malcolm. "The one near here is a lovely big house, with acres of green grass around it, and orchards and vine-yards, and they are ever so good to the children, and give them plenty to eat and wear, and send them to school."
column3: They don't shut you up when they send you to an asylum, said Malcolm. "The one near here is a lovely big house, with acres of green grass around it, and orchards and vine yards, and they are ever so good to the children, and give them plenty to eat and wear, and send them to school."

column2: Barney wouldn't be there, sobbed Jonesy, diving under the pillow again.
column3: Barney wouldn't be there, sobbed Jonesy, diving under the pillow again.

column2: I don't want nothing but him.
column3: I don't want nothing but him.

column2: Well, we'll see what we can do, said Malcolm, as he heard the professor coming back.
column3: Well, we'll see what we can do, said Malcolm, as he heard the professor coming back.

column2: If we could only keep you here until spring, I am sure that papa would send you back all right.	If we could only keep you here until spring, I am sure that papa would send you back all right.
column3: true

column2: He's always helping people that get into trouble."
column3: He's always helping people that get into trouble."

column2: Jonesy took his little snub nose out of the pillow as the professor came in, and looked around defiantly as if ready to fight the first one who dared to hint that he had been crying.
column3: Jonesy took his little snub nose out of the pillow as the professor came in, and looked around defiantly as if ready to fight the first one who dared to hint that he had been crying.

column2: The boys took their leave soon after, leading the bear back to his new quarters in the carriage house, where they had made him a comfortable den.
column3: The boys took their leave soon after, leading the bear back to his new quarters in the carriage house, where they had made him a comfortable den.

column2: Then they walked slowly up to the house, their arms thrown across each other's shoulders.
column3: Then they walked slowly up to the house, their arms thrown across each other's shoulders.

column2: S'pose it was us, said Keith, after walking on a little way in silence.
column3: S'pose it was us, said Keith, after walking on a little way in silence.

column2: S'pose that you and I were left of all the family, and didn't have any friends in the world, and I was to get separated from you and couldn't get back?
column3: S'pose that you and I were left of all the family, and didn't have any friends in the world, and I was to get separated from you and couldn't get back?

column2: That would be tough luck, for sure, answered Malcolm.
column3: That would be tough luck, for sure, answered Malcolm.

column2: Don't you s'pose Jonesy feels as badly about it as we would? asked Keith.
column3: Don't you s'pose Jonesy feels as badly about it as we would? asked Keith.

column2: Shouldn't be surprised, said Malcolm, beginning to whistle.
column3: Shouldn't be surprised, said Malcolm, beginning to whistle.

column2: Keith joined in, and keeping step to the tune, like two soldiers, they marched on into the house.
column3: Keith joined in, and keeping step to the tune, like two soldiers, they marched on into the house.

column2: Virginia found them in the library, a little while later, sitting on the hearth-rug, tailor-fashion.
column3: Virginia found them in the library, a little while later, sitting on the hearth rug, tailor fashion.

column2: They were still talking about Jonesy.
column3: They were still talking about Jonesy.

column2: They could think of nothing else but the loneliness of the little waif, and his pitiful appeal: "Oh, don't let them shut me up where I can't never get back to Barney."
column3: They could think of nothing else but the loneliness of the little waif, and his pitiful appeal: "Oh, don't let them shut me up where I can't never get back to Barney."

column2: Why don't you write to your father? asked Virginia, when they had told her the story of their visit.
column3: Why don't you write to your father? asked Virginia, when they had told her the story of their visit.

column2: Oh, it is so hard to explain things in a letter, answered Malcolm, "and being off there, he'd say that grandmother and all the grown people certainly know best.
column3: Oh, it is so hard to explain things in a letter, answered Malcolm, "and being off there, he'd say that grandmother and all the grown people certainly know best.

column2: But if he could see Jonesy,--how pitiful looking he is, and hear him crying to go back to his brother, I know he'd feel the way we do about it."
column3: But if he could see Jonesy,--how pitiful looking he is, and hear him crying to go back to his brother, I know he'd feel the way we do about it."

column2: I called the professor out in the hall, and told him so, said Keith, "and asked him if he couldn't adopt Jonesy, or something, until papa comes home.
column3: I called the professor out in the hall, and told him so, said Keith, "and asked him if he couldn't adopt Jonesy, or something, until papa comes home.

column2: But he said that he is too poor.
column3: But he said that he is too poor.

column2: He has only a few dollars a month to live on.
column3: He has only a few dollars a month to live on.

column2: I didn't mind asking him.
column3: I didn't mind asking him.

column2: He smiled in that big, kind way he always does.
column3: He smiled in that big, kind way he always does.

column2: He said Jonesy was lots of company, and he would like to keep him this summer, if he could afford it, and let him get well and strong out here in the country."
column3: He said Jonesy was lots of company, and he would like to keep him this summer, if he could afford it, and let him get well and strong out here in the country."

column2: Then he would keep him till Uncle Sydney comes, if somebody would pay his board? asked Virginia.
column3: Then he would keep him till Uncle Sydney comes, if somebody would pay his board? asked Virginia.

column2: Yes, said Malcolm, "but that doesn't help matters much, for we children are the only ones who want him to stay, and our monthly allowances, all put together, wouldn't be enough."
column3: Yes, said Malcolm, "but that doesn't help matters much, for we children are the only ones who want him to stay, and our monthly allowances, all put together, wouldn't be enough."

column2: We might earn the money ourselves, suggested Virginia, after awhile, breaking a long silence.
column3: We might earn the money ourselves, suggested Virginia, after awhile, breaking a long silence.

column2: How? demanded Malcolm.
column3: How? demanded Malcolm.

column2: Now, Ginger, you know, as well as I do, there is no way for us to earn anything this time of year.	Now, Ginger, you know, as well as I do, there is no way for us to earn anything this time of year.

column2: You can't pick fruit in the dead of winter, can you? or pull weeds, or rake leaves? What other way is there?"
column3: You can't pick fruit in the dead of winter, can you? or pull weeds, or rake leaves? What other way is there?"

column2: We might go to every house in the valley, and exhibit the bear, said Keith, "taking up a collection each time."
column3: We might go to every house in the valley, and exhibit the bear, said Keith, "taking up a collection each time."

column2: Now you've made me think of it, cried Virginia, excitedly.
column3: Now you've made me think of it, cried Virginia, excitedly.

column2: I've thought of a good way.	I've thought of a good way.
column3: true

column2: We'll give Jonesy a benefit, like great singers have.
column3: We'll give Jonesy a benefit, like great singers have.

column2: The bear will be the star performer, and we'll all act, too, and sell the tickets, and have tableaux.
column3: The bear will be the star performer, and we'll all act, too, and sell the tickets, and have tableaux.

column2: I love to arrange tableaux.
column3: I love to arrange tableaux.

column2: We were always having them out at the fort."
column3: We were always having them out at the fort."

column2: I bid to show off the bear, cried Malcolm, entering into Virginia's plan at once.
column3: I bid to show off the bear, cried Malcolm, entering into Virginia's plan at once.

column2: May be I'll learn something to recite, too.
column3: May be I'll learn something to recite, too.

column2: I'll help print the tickets, said Keith, "and go around selling them, and be in anything you want me to be.
column3: I'll help print the tickets, said Keith, "and go around selling them, and be in anything you want me to be.

column2: How many tableaux are you going to have, Ginger?"
column3: How many tableaux are you going to have, Ginger?"

column2: I can't tell yet, she answered, but a moment after she cried out, her eyes shining with pleasure, "Oh, I've thought of a lovely one.
column3: I can't tell yet, she answered, but a moment after she cried out, her eyes shining with pleasure, "Oh, I've thought of a lovely one.

column2: We can have the Little Colonel and the bear for 'Beauty and the Beast.'"
column3: We can have the Little Colonel and the bear for 'Beauty and the Beast.'"

column2: Malcolm promptly turned a somersault on the rug, to express his approval, but came up with a grave face, saying, "I'll bet that grandmother will say we can't have it."
column3: Malcolm promptly turned a somersault on the rug, to express his approval, but came up with a grave face, saying, "I'll bet that grandmother will say we can't have it."

column2: Let's get Aunt Allison on our side, suggested Virginia.
column3: Let's get Aunt Allison on our side, suggested Virginia.

column2: She's up in her room now, painting a picture.
column3: She's up in her room now, painting a picture.

column2: A little sigh of disappointment escaped Miss Allison's lips, as she heard the rush of feet on the stairs.
column3: A little sigh of disappointment escaped Miss Allison's lips, as she heard the rush of feet on the stairs.

column2: This was the first time that she had touched her brushes since the children's coming, and she had hoped that this one afternoon would be free from interruption, when she heard them planning their afternoon's occupations at the lunch-table.
column3: This was the first time that she had touched her brushes since the children's coming, and she had hoped that this one afternoon would be free from interruption, when she heard them planning their afternoon's occupations at the lunch table.

column2: They had come back before the little water-colour sketch she was making was quite finished.

column2: There was no disappointment, however, in the bright face she turned toward them, and Virginia lost no time in beginning her story.
column3: There was no disappointment, however, in the bright face she turned toward them, and Virginia lost no time in beginning her story.

column2: She had been elected to tell it, but before it was done all three had had a part in the telling, and all three were waiting with wistful eyes for her answer.
column3: She had been elected to tell it, but before it was done all three had had a part in the telling, and all three were waiting with wistful eyes for her answer.

column2: Well, what is it you want me to do? she asked, finally.
column3: Well, what is it you want me to do? she asked, finally.

column2: Oh, just be on our side! they exclaimed, "and get grandmother to say yes.
column3: Oh, just be on our side! they exclaimed, "and get grandmother to say yes.

column2: You see she doesn't feel about Jonesy the way we do.
column3: You see she doesn't feel about Jonesy the way we do.

column2: She is willing to pay a great deal of money to have him taken off and cared for, but she says she doesn't see how grandchildren of hers can be so interested in a little tramp that comes from nobody knows where, and who will probably end his days in a penitentiary."

column3: Aunt Allison answered Malcolm's last remark a little sternly.

column3: You must understand that it is only for your own good that she is opposed to Jonesy's staying, she said.

column2: There is nobody in the valley so generous and kind to the poor as your grandmother. "Yes'm," said Virginia, meekly, "but you'll ask her, won't you please, auntie?"
column3: There is nobody in the valley so generous and kind to the poor as your grandmother. "Yes'm," said Virginia, meekly, "but you'll ask her, won't you please, auntie?"

column2: Miss Allison smiled at her persistence.

column2: Yes, they cried in chorus, "you're on our side.

column2: When Miss Allison kept her promise she did not go to her mother with the children's story of Jonesy, to move her to pity.
column3: When Miss Allison kept her promise she did not go to her mother with the children's story of Jonesy, to move her to pity.

column2: She told her simply what they wanted, and then said, "Mother, you know I have begun to teach the children the 'Vision of Sir Launfal.' Virginia has learned every word of it, and the boys will soon know all but the preludes.

column2: There will never be a better chance than this for them to learn the lesson:
column3: There will never be a better chance than this for them to learn the lesson:

This would be a real sharing of themselves, all their time and best energies, for they will have to work hard to get up such an entertainment as this.

column2: It isn't for Jonesy's sake I ask it, but for the children's own good."

column2: The old lady looked thoughtfully into the fire a moment, and then said, "Maybe you are right, Allison.
column3: The old lady looked thoughtfully into the fire a moment, and then said, "Maybe you are right, Allison.

column2: I do want to keep them unspotted from a knowledge of the world's evils, but I do not want to make them selfish. If this little beggar at the gate can teach them where to find the Holy Grail, through unselfish service to him, I do not want to stand in the way.
column3: I do want to keep them unspotted from a knowledge of the world's evils, but I do not want to make them selfish. If this little beggar at the gate can teach them where to find the Holy Grail, through unselfish service to him, I do not want to stand in the way.

column2: Bless their little hearts, they may play Sir Launfal if they want to, and may they have as beautiful a vision as his!"
